item.title: Syntax highlighting using Pygments
item.description: I've added a super simple way to enable colourful code syntax highlighting for any code blocks you publish (requires Pygments to be installed, which needs Python). No JavaScript is required by the visitors browser, as the highlighting is done at build time.<!--1553663737-->

item.title: Dynamic search page using Jets
item.description: I've added a search.html page, which is auto-generated by the `rebuild` command, so users can search the website and its posts more easily. The results are presented in a nice list, just like a normal search engine results page.<!--1553663736-->

item.title: Improving SEO with JSON-LD Breadcrumbs
item.description: Using linked data breadcrumbs, we can help search engines map the structure of our site, and owrk out the relationships between pages.<!--1553663736-->

item.title: Unpublishing pages
item.description: An easy way to hide pages on the site, without deleting them, so you can continue working on them, or publish them again later.<!--1553663735-->

item.title: Added a `.gitignore` file
item.description: Only HTML, CSS, JS and other site assets will be deployed to the server - all source files remain on the local machine only.<!--1553663735-->

item.title: Adding HTML and CSS minification
item.description: A new feature has been added to `mdsh` which will improve site performance: automatic minification of the generated HTML and CSS.<!--1553663734-->

item.title: Fixing code formatting
item.description: Another IFS based fix for processing input while retaining any whitespace.<!--1553663734-->

item.title: Enabling easier Markdown re-building
item.description: A new script called `mdsh2md` has been added to the suite of commands available in `mdsh`. This new script makes it easy to build valid Markdown files from the custom `mdsh` format files used when writing posts.<!--1553663733-->

item.title: Setting up your blog
item.description: I've added a couple of scripts that make the initial setup of your blog easier, as well as running the web server.<!--1553663733-->

item.title: Highlighting search terms on the page
item.description: Using a small Cash-JS plugin (adapted from a jQuery plugin), we can easily highlight the users given search terms where they are found on the page.<!--1553663732-->

item.title: Custom CSS and JS for every page
item.description: A simple solution for adding custom CSS and JavaScript to any page or post you create using `mdsh` has now been implemented.<!--1553663732-->

item.title: Searching this website
item.description: I've made it easier to search the website, by enabling Jets powered site search on more pages.<!--1553663731-->

item.title: Fixing RSS generation
item.description: The differences between the GNU and BSD version of `date`, `find` and `sed` caused the RSS feed generation to fail on Mac OS X. So here is how I fixed it.<!--1553663731-->

item.title: Adding authors pages
item.description: Listing all blog post authors, and the posts they've written, in a nice searchable way is now possible in `mdsh`.<!--1553663730-->

item.title: Generating better homepages
item.description: The auto generated homepages have been greatly improved - by default they now list your sites most recent posts in full, instead of listing only the titles of each. This is a much nicer experience for users who land on your homepage.<!--1553663730-->

item.title: Adding a site search feature
item.description: I'm using Jets (https://github.com/NeXTs/Jets.js) for my site search, as it provides very fast, filter-as-you-type page searching.<!--1553663730-->

item.title: Generating an XML sitemap
item.description: Here is a bash script for generating a valid XML sitemap file (sitemap.xml), which can be used to improve the SEO of your website, and improve your Google search rankings.<!--1553663729-->

item.title: Generating an RSS feed
item.description: An RSS feed is a great way to tell users about new content - they can easily subscribe to your RSS feed and be notified when a new post had been published. RSS feeds can be viewed in browser or a dedicated news reader.<!--1553663729-->
